content.description:
Start up a ramp that leads up and left to the 1st bolt and then launch up the vertical face on positive but spaced edges. The crux is near the top and requires good balance, a cool head and faith in the next holds.

An area classic and one of the early sport routes here that showed the potential of the crag.

About the name -

brautigan.net/trout.html

.
content.location: Located on the east face of Fisherman's Buttress, this is the 2nd route from the right.

content.description: Hand traverse the edge of a left-slanting ramp past two bolts then cut right in an angling crack to finish.
content.protection: 2 bolts, gear to 4 inches, bolted anchors (shared with Roadside Crack)
content.location: Starts just left of Roadside Crack and with the first two bolts of Catch of the Day.

climbs.name: Shadowcaster
climbs.fa: (TR) Chris Miller, April 2001, Direct Start (TR) Dave LePere, August 2002, FL: Unknown, 2003

content.description: Angle in from the right on a slanting seam (original start) or climb directly (thinner) to reach a vertical offset seam which provides the off-balance crux. Above the crux the climbing eases to 5.11 and stays interesting to the anchors.

Stem the corner past a bolt (crux) and mantle onto a ledge, then step into the splitter (5.8) and jam your way to anchors. The rock is a little rough in spots, but feet are abundant, especially higher up.
content.protection: One bolt gear to 2.5 inches, chain anchor
content.location: Located slightly right of center and easily identified as a right-facing corner to a splitter crack.

content.description: Climbs easy but interesting face that trends slightly right to a reachy crux at the last bolt; taller climbers will have an easier time at the crux.
content.location: Between Shadowcaster and Trout Fishing in America and further identified by a solitary belay bolt at the base.

content.description: Stem and jam the mostly thin crack to a ledge and then follow featured face to the arete of Fishbone, joining at the 3rd bolt of that route.
content.protection: 3 bolts, gear to 2 inches, anchors (shared with Fishbone).
content.location: Starts in a short crack between Fishbone and Catfish Crack.

content.description:
Awkward climbing on the arete on the far left side of the east face. Careful footwork is necessary along with interesting hand placement in order to send this tricky 5.10b.

Using the block on the right makes the climb an enjoyable 5.9 route.
Interesting and unusual moves past a couple bolts lead into a flaring seam and a short bit of face at the top.
content.location: Starts just right of Catfish Crack and left of a huge pine tree.

climbs.name: Catfish Crack
climbs.fa: Brad Singer, Eric Tipton & Eric Odenthal, October 1999

content.description:
Stem and lieback to a hand crack above the A-frame roof and then up to the top of a large block - 2 stars for this section.

The climb continues up a dirty, awkward and unpleasant crack to finish - zero stars, but a better option is to move over left and finish on

Fishbone

- 2 stars.

Gear belay or belay from bolts to the right (Fish Out of Water) but make sure to set a directional for your follower.
content.location:
Located on the far left, right of

Fishbone

and at a prominent A-frame roof.

climbs.name: Catch of the Day
climbs.fa: (TR) Chris Miller & Rick Corbin, July 2000, FL: Chris Miller, July 2000

content.description: Hand traverse the arete of the slanting ramp and when the ramp ends pull onto the face to the left and into an engaging sequence of thin edges on the bulging face. Once past the crux the angle eases and fun climbing on edges gains the anchors.
content.location:
Left of

Roadside Crack

at a left-slanting ramp system.

content.description:
Start directly on the arete and make crimpy moves to a horizontal and get ready for the fun above. Bearhug the arete to a crux encounter at the third bolt and finish up vertical face past several horizontals and good exposure.

Excellent moves and exposure on this route - get on it!
content.location:
On the northeast arete just right of

Trout Fishing in America

.

climbs.name: Angler
climbs.fa: Chris Miller and Rick Corbin, July 2000

content.description:
Romp up a dirty slab to gain the obvious right- slanting crack which is followed to the top.

Might make a decent lead if someone scrubbed the lichen and added a few bolts down low.
content.protection: TR from anchors atop Roadside Crack.
content.location: Starts just left of Roadside Crack on a dirty, lichen covered ramp.
